title: Post Office failed to set up my direct debit then charged me
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sat, Aug 1, 2015, 08:53 BST - UK Markets closed Post Office failed to set up my direct debit then charged me By Jessica Gorst-Williams | Telegraph – 21 hours ago Print 
A reader is penalised for paying her credit card bill late following the Post Office's failure to set up a direct debit 
Last year I set up a direct debit for payments to be taken from my TSB current account to settle my Post Office credit card bill on a monthly basis. While visiting my daughter in Australia I logged into my bank account and discovered that no payment had been taken. I immediately stopped using my credit card. 
On my return to Britain I went into the local post office and paid by cheque the full amount it was demanding including a £24 fee for late payment. I complained about the situation and the Post Office gave compensation. 
• 'My bank account switch left bills unpaid' 
• 'Santander isn't acknowledging payments made from other Santander accounts why?' 
Under the impression that the matter had been sorted out, I again used my Post Office credit card. The direct debit did not work this time either. Valerie Singleton, Devon 
This time a £12 late payment charge with interest featured on your statement. Then the Post Office said TSB had refused to make the credit card payment. Ridiculously at one stage it told you your bank did not exist, even though it had managed to pay the goodwill sum directly into the account. 
The Post Office told me it had liaised with TSB and between the systems there had been an error that was now rectified. As a new gesture of goodwill it sent £175. 
When I spoke to TSB, it turned out that the direct debit was still not in place. It knew nothing of the issue and robustly said it had never rejected the request for payment. The problem had come about because the Post Office's systems had not recognised the sort code. 
Eventually the Post Office admitted that the sort code required by the Post Office to collect the direct debit payment from TSB had not been loaded on to its processing system. It has been now. 
The Post Office would come out of this with less egg on its face if it had fully acknowledged what had happened first time around. 
You won’t be using your Post Office card any more.
